posts.cooked:
Hello, Iâ€™m here to share a project we developed for the Reefscape seasonâ€”and explain how you can build it yourself.

First, you can browse our code on GitHub:

GitHub - Giro-FRC/AdvantageKitSwerve: AdvantageKitSwerve in off season AdvantageKitSwerve in off season

AdvantageKitSwerve in off season

Hardware setup:

Motors: 8 Ã— NEO brushless motors

Motor controllers: 8 Ã— Spark MAX

IMU: NavX 2.0

The core idea is simple: detect which zone of the field the robot is in, then automatically align it to the nearest reef. To do this reliably you need strong odometryâ€”so we recommend integrating a vision system.

If youâ€™re ready, letâ€™s dive in.

We use PathPlanner to generate trajectories on the fly. In a dedicated class (e.g. GoToPath ), youâ€™ll:

Define a function that accepts the robotâ€™s current pose and a target pose.

Supply the coordinates of each reefâ€‘alignment point as inputs.

Let PathPlanner compute the optimal trajectory for you.

Note: We mirror this same helper function in our AutoAlignment class so that all alignment logic stays together.

To determine where the robot is on the field, we model each area of interest as a polygon. In a FieldPolygon class, you:

List the corner points (as Xâ€“Y coordinates) of each region.

Combine those points logically (e.g. with && ) to form complex shapes.

Query at runtime whether the robotâ€™s current pose lies within any given polygon.

The result in your dashboard might look like this:

The final piece lives in your AutoAlignment class. On each loop:

Read the drivetrainâ€™s current pose.

Check which zone polygon contains that pose.

Determine the nearest reefâ€‘alignment point to that pose.

Schedule a command to drive along the computed path to the reef.

This simple if/else logic lets the robot automatically chooseâ€”and align toâ€”the closest reef whenever it enters its zone.

Yesâ€”weâ€™ve reached the end of the guide. Thank you for reading! Since this is my first guide and I used translation tools, my English may have a few mistakes; I apologize in advance. If you run into any issues, donâ€™t hesitate to let me know. Stay with FRC !

Edit: Video

Google Drive file.

posts.cooked:
I think the entire zoning approach is superfluous. Each reef face has an April tag, which can be converted to a Pose2d object. Using the robot pose, you can do

and itâ€™ll give you the closest one.
Thank you very much for your suggestion. I didnâ€™t know that, I can update the project in a free time.

posts.name: Oliver
posts.cooked: additionally, you can get a list of poses of the reef poles (or the positions you need to be to score at each reef pole) by applying two transforms to each april tag, one for the left reef pole and one for the right. then use the nearest method as before. we do it like this

Thanks for your suggestion, unfortunately we could only throw coral to the L1 part because we made an everybot this year. Since there is no elevator system that I can test in real life, I adjusted it according to the L1 part.

posts.name: Val DiBona
posts.cooked: We did something similar to this however we do it at runtime and go from the closest tag to the pose2D of the target location for auto alignment by using the closest tag you get a nice diagram of regions: From there we add an offset for whether we want the LEFT, RIGHT, or MIDDLE of the reef side (enum with the transformations).

I came across this in the golden horn teamâ€™s behind to bumper video. You can see it at 4.37 minutes. I would be very happy if we can help each other on this subject.

posts.cooked: First of all, thank you for being one of the inspirations for me in this project. Although I have reviewed your code, I still canâ€™t understand how you redirect these fields to advantagescope. I would be very grateful if you could help me.

posts.name: Cole Hunt
posts.cooked:
We use a StructArrayPublisher .  There is a simple example uses poses on the AdvantageScope documentation page. ðŸ—º Odometry | AdvantageScope

Our implementation is just as simple. We define the region via an array of Translation2ds in the Region constructor. mainbot-2025/src/main/java/frc/mw_lib/geometry/PolygonRegion.java at af933ead440049fdd6b675a961c8f6d460a8c862 Â· FRC-Team-4143/mainbot-2025 Â· GitHub . You can see line 30-33 are setting up the struct array publisher similar to the AdvantageScope docs example, but using the Translation2d struct instead of Pose2d.

Then we call logPoints which is a custom method that just sends a value to that previously defined publisher. That value is just the Translation2d array that was given in the class constructor. mainbot-2025/src/main/java/frc/mw_lib/geometry/PolygonRegion.java at af933ead440049fdd6b675a961c8f6d460a8c862 Â· FRC-Team-4143/mainbot-2025 Â· GitHub

posts.name: Cole Hunt
posts.cooked:
It looks like your implementation is a little different than ours. You are creating a single class that just checks a preset list of points. Our implementation is meant to be universal for any size/shape of polygon. We then create multiple PolygonRegion objects to define our different field zones.

If you want to continue with your implementation you will need to create a Pose2d or Translation2d array for each point in your zone polygon. For example:

I donâ€™t fully understand your apporach, but that would be an example of a 2 point â€œpolygonâ€ that you could publish to NT using a StructArrayPublisher. I would expect it to just look like a line in AdvantageScope.

Here is an example of a Translation2d array we made for our loading station zone. It is just a Triangle in the corner of the field.

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
You can! The Field2D object supports arbitrary objects via field.getObject(â€œnameâ€). Our testing consisted of

Simulating the chassis

Grabbing the nearest tag, and then setting a pose for it on a field

Generating appropriate transforms, adding those to the field

Repeating for any other items of interest

If you want to actually make lines, you can use the .setPoses(....) method , and then change the display style on the dashboard. At least on Glass, thereâ€™s a number of display options to get really useful visualizations. Not sure about Advantagescope specifically. You can also setPoses using field trajectories, and do other interesting things on it, such as setting a specific object name to an image.

Thank you very much for your help. I finally managed to add these lines with the help of chatgpt. I pushed the new code to the repo, you can check it if you want.

But the comment lines are written in Turkish for my team to understand for now, soon I will translate all these lines into English, I would appreciate if you ignore this.
